headline: Christmas Prime Rib
description: A prime rib dinner is a splendid choice for Christmas! This recipe features a Dijon mustard crust and provides the perfect roasting time for prime rib.

video.description: A flavorful, melt in your mouth, classic Christmas dish.
video.name: Christmas Prime Rib

name: Christmas Prime Rib
recipeIngredient: 1 small unpeeled onion, quartered and separated

recipeInstructions.text: The day before serving, remove the roast from the package and dry thoroughly with paper towels. Set roast on a baking sheet, and place in refrigerator overnight. Remove from refrigerator 1 hour before cooking to allow meat to reach room temperature. Rub the roast all over with horseradish and Dijon mustard. Mix kosher salt, black pepper, thyme, and garlic powder together in small bowl; sprinkle over the roast.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C). Place celery, carrot, and onion into the bottom of a roasting pan; place the roast on top.

Roast in the preheated oven for 30 minutes. Reduce oven temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and roast until the meat is browned and an instant-read meat thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the roast reads 130 degrees F (54 degrees C) for medium-rare. Remove from oven, transfer roast to a platter, and cover with a tent of aluminum foil. Allow to rest for 30 minutes. The temperature of the meat will rise about 10 degrees during resting time.

To make au jus sauce: Skim excess fat from pan drippings in the roasting pan. Place the pan over a burner set to medium heat; stir in beef base and 1 1/2 cups of water. Bring to a boil, scraping and dissolving any brown flavor bits from the bottom of the pan. Strain out and discard vegetables. Combine cornstarch and 1 teaspoon of water in a small bowl; whisk the mixture into sauce. Allow sauce to thicken slightly; pour into a gravy boat and serve with roast.

review.reviewBody: Today's Christmas Family Feast. I've made this numerous times and it always is absolutely mouthwatering!

We loved the recipe. It was the first time I've made prime rib. I followed the recipe as directed but did follow the baking suggestions of reviewer Elizabeth. The meat was so tender we could cut it with a fork & had excellent flavor. A month later and my husband is still remarking how much he enjoyed the meal.

Only thing I did different was I smoked it. It turned out awesome! I let it sit or for about 2 hours with the rub on and put it in the smoker while it warmed up to get the extra smoke into it. Cooked it to 135 degrees by meat probe. It was a perfect medium rare.

It was soooo delicious. My hubs got a wireless thermometer for Christmas, and we kept track of it with his phone. It was perfect. We made pigs of ourselves. I did add a bit of Williams Sonoma Mushroom gravy starter to this recipe, and the gravy was superb. Mine was a 3 rib/7.5lbs. Will def make again.
Made this for Christmas dinner. Delicious! Everyone loved the flavor. This recipe is our new go to for prime rib!
Family loved it!!!

This Prime Rib was fantastic. I didn't make there AuJus, we had never had one that was thick. So we left out the veggie step and made our usual Au Jus. I love the crust too. This will defintely be our go to Prime Rib recipe. Thank you!

I was a little worried about making this dish because I’ve never made prime rib, nor do I eat it, but my family insists I make the best steaks so I thought I’d give this one a try. It was a major hit. For other first timers like me, I wouldn’t worry about getting the ingredients exactly right. It’s the cut of the meat and the cooking method that really gives this one flavor. If you’ve read other recipes, chef john’s prime rib is very basic and has over 2k 5 star reviews. Like other reviewers I set the oven to 500 degrees and cooked a 4.5lb roast for 30 mins. Then I reduced the heat to 350 for about 30 mins making sure to not open the oven door. Then I turned the oven completely off leaving the roast in the oven for an additional 30 minutes. I followed the rest of the recipe as described. My family likes their prime rib a little more done than most people. It was perfect, a true medium. Everyone loved it even the picky toddlers who only eat mac & cheese! You should definitely give this one a try.

Made this Christmas Eve, the most delicious prime rib I have ever cooked!!! Kept to the recipe with a 4.5 lb bone in roast. Took it out of the oven when meat thermometer registered 120 degrees. Let it rest for 30 minutes tented with foil and was a perfect medium rare!

I made this for Christmas dinner and a turkey breast. The Prim Rib was so tender and full of flavor. My family loved it.
Gus...
Hardest part getting herb de provdance. It was very good
Made as written but had a 5 lbs roast. Delicious, better than a restaurant. I cooked mine until 140 degrees for a medium rare roast- more towards medium than rare as I don't like rawer cuts of meat.

I swapped out a Rib Eye roast for the Prime Rib and cooked it on an rotisserie BBQ. Everything else was essentially the same and it turned out perfectly. Cooked till internal temp of 130 F and then let it stand for 30 mins. Med rare on the ends and rare in the middle. This gets better each time we do it.

I made this for Christmas Dinner. The seasonings enhanced the flavor of the beef, The gravy made from the pan veggies and some reserved pan juices was very tasty. The meat and gravy was delicious. Will definitely make it again!

This recipe was unclear as to roasting time. A time estimate for size/lbs should have been given. Also the high temperature for the first 30 minutes burned the rub. Rub ingredients fabulous and yummy though!! And I should have increased the vegetable bed to include as a side or garnish with the au jus

Giving this one 4 stars since the au jus didn't turn out so hot. The veggies and the juices just ended up drying up to burnt scrapings on the bottom of the pan. I added the water and beef base and cooked it, but it was just too much carbon. I re-did the au jus with beef base (Better Than Bouillon) and some seasonings. Letting the roast rest in a pan for 30 minutes gave me some juice to add to the sauce later, so it wasn't a total failure. But the horseradish/dijon mustard on the meat before roasting was great! The house smelled amazing and the taste of the meat was lovely!

The coating was amazing! I will never use anything else! I cooked at 325 like some other reviews recommended and took it out of the oven at 118 F. I left it to rest while I finished the rest of dinner - it was at 132 F by the time we were ready. I think I will take it out just a little sooner next time. But it was still spectacular!
It was perfect, I didn't change anything. The best prime rib so far. Thanks for the recipe.
Perfect as written. Did let it sit out for about 4 hours prior to putting in oven.
Delicious!
this recipe is very tasty and easy to follow

Amazing!!! This is my second time making prime rib and I was nervous because I didn’t love it the first time. I loved it this time. I changed nothing as far as ingredients. My roast was 6.8lbs. I forgot to take it out of the package and dry it overnight in the fridge but I did it for a couple hours this AM. I left my roast on the counter for 1.5 hours. Cooked it at 450 for 40m and then 350 for 2hours (130 degrees is when I took it out). It sat for 45m to rest. It was a medium cut. This is how we prefer it. However I think 15 less minutes in the oven and it would be medium rare.

I’m confused, we (British) love roast beef, but today (and in all my 69 years) a traditional Christmas meal is turkey!! I’m not saying that it’s true for all Brits, but it’s definitely true of the majority. There was a time when goose was traditional, now it’s much too expensive for most households.
it is delicious! and added potatoes with it... amazing

Awesome, thank you!
I will make it again!
Absolutely fantastic. Didn't even discard the veggies - saving them for a soup later with the bones. YUM.

We made this for Christmas 2019, everybody loved it - looks like it will become an annual Christmas Tradition! Followed the recipe as is and also invested in a quality meat thermometer - high recommend it!

I was very nervous to cook this very expensive prime rib for Christmas dinner guests. I turned out perfect. Followed the recipe exactly. The au jus sauce thickened up the more it sat. The meat was so tender and flavorful. Will definitely make this again!
excellent if you get the boneless prime rib choose

For a 4 ribs size, I cooked it for one hour at 475 then I turned down to 400 until my temp was 150 , about another 45 min I think. Then I covered until the turkey was done. So tender and the crust was perfect. Everybody was talking about it.
Made minor changes and the family loved. Will definitely make this again.

This recipe was absolutely DELICIOUS! I made this prime rib yesterday for company and was not sure if they would like it. Big success! Just enough flavor and meat was so tender everyone was cutting it with their forks. The only mistake that I made was not leaving it in long enough but was able to put it back in the oven and cook it a little longer. I based my timing for a 4 lb roast. I will definitely be making this again. Will go according to the cooking time though.
Very moist and juicy! The flavor was perfect and the au jus was a hit!
I made it just like the recipe said. It came out awesome. I would definitely make it again. Love it.
Best prime rip I’ve ever made. Followed the recipe exactly it was perfect.
I will absolutely make this again! I followed the directions (including the cooking time) verbatim. The prime rib turned out amazing. Even my 9 and 7 year old loved it!

Fantastic recipe!
Prime rib us expensive, so Inwanted a "no regrets" experience. I scored a discounted 6 lb roast at the butcher, and followed the recipe very closely. However, I left the bones in, and had to guess at the cook time. Mine was closer to medium than mid rare. Still delicious. Highly recommend.
This was amazing. Never made prime rib before. Wouldn’t change a thing!!!
Delicious...Quick....Easy....
Made this twice in December. Once for 4 adults, once Christmas Day for 8 adults. There were NO leftovers.
Used real garlic and onions

I had never made prime rib before but wanted to make one for our family xmas dinner. Trialed a 3lb prime rib for me and my husband and he loved it and said his family would def love it! Made a 9lb version for xmas dinner with my in laws and it was a hit! The recipe is so simple and the directions are so easy to follow; this recipe is amaaaazing!! It’s soooo good! Actually going to be making it again for my sister in law and her bf this weekend for dinner per their request.
I made this with a 11 lb round eye roast on Christmas and everyone loved it. I had french dips with the leftovers even my finicky brother loved it .
Great flavor, easy to make.
Once again it turned out Fantastic! It’s not just for Christmas anymore!

was always afraid to try a prime rib until now. we used a pair of 3lb cowboy steaks, which is esssentially the prime rib still attached to a large piece of rib bone. 

the recipe was super simple to follow to make it fool proof. the flavors were spot on, but i did use the dry seasoning more as a light rub on the outside edges.

everyone loved it. cant wait to try this with a 12 lb roast.

At least a week before I put garlic cloves halved into the meat ( I love garlic). I also let the meat rest at room temporarily at least 1 1/2 hours ( depends on the weight) before grilling any meat! The au jus can be made with flour (it’s heavier than cornstarch) also. Great seasoning!

Follow the times and temp, but I rub butter over the whole thing and lots of salt and pepper, I used Herbs de Provence. The 12.5ib roast came out at 140 internal after 24 minutes at 450 and 2 hours and change at 350. Christmas eve we ate half and the day after we sliced and reheat in broth and made the best sammies ever. Anything over 145 is garbage fit only for a dog you don't like. I will pan grill for those who can't do Mid- rare. But I will give you an evil eye while I am doing it. The son-in-law ran off with the bones saying something about his grill and being his.
Cooked a little too long. Should have removed at 115. Otherwise best I’ve had!
The paste was a nice addition.

I was a bit nervous about the coating, but it was universally pronounced "to die for"! I had an 8 pound roast and had plenty to cover the meat. I did not use vegetables, but the drippings were still good enough to make the au jus.

I followed Elizabeth Detrich review and the prime rib came out perfect and delicious. Thanks Elizabeth. I like my prime rib on the pink side so next time I will keep in oven after baking for 1 1/2 hours and not the 2 hours.
Turned out good but sadly overdone. Should have removed at 130 not 135. Gravy just meh. Not sure why but little seasonings in it. Needed lotsa work to correct. Will try a different recipe

I just made this. Followed the directions as listed and it was fabulous (if I may say so myself lol.) I got rave reviews from everyone at Christmas dinner. I bought an14 plus lb bone in prime rib. I had the butcher cut off bone then tie it back on. I cut off about a third of the roast and froze for another day. I was a little worried that the horseradish rub would be too spicy for a few of my guests but the cooking process rendered the horseradish into a very tasty crust.
I made it as written and it was excellent. I will definitely make it again

This was my first attempt making Prime Rib. I also must confess I never had Prime Rib in my life. However, Christmas 2018 was a special one and I wanted to offer my guests a main course that was not the traditional ham. 

This was OUTSTANDING!

Not knowing what I was doing, I purchased a prime rib with bone. This ended up increasing the overall cooking time by a hour. I made the crust and placed it in the oven at 11:30am. By 2:30pm the roast was complete. I let it sit 30 mins. By 3:00pm, we were ready to eat. 

My guests had nothing but good things to say about the tenderness of the roast and the crust. They were extremely surprised when I showed them this simple recipe. They were under the impression, (similar to what I was until I found this recipe) you needed to cook the roast at a high temperature (500 degrees) then let it cool down for hours without opening the oven door. Now, I am not discrediting those recipes that instruct this method. I am sure there are reasons for this , but in a land of wannabe foodies this recipe was perfection! 

It made our Christmas 2018 so memorable.
This is the third year I will be making this. It makes. Wonderful crust on the roast that really seals in the juices.
My roast was 12 pounds, I doubled everything and was delicious!

I made this today for a dinner party. It was great! It had a nice tasty crust. I dry aged the 6 lbs of prime rib Choice for 2 days and let the roast come to room temperature for 90 min. I used a thermometer from my over set to 130F. After the 30 min roast at 450F, the roast took another 1 hour 15 mins in a convection oven to reach 130F. Perfect!
The cut of beef is important. Don’t buy a cheaper cut -enjoy the flavour of a better cut.
Great recipe and easy to make. Family loved it!!

This is a great recipe and it turned out beautifully! It wasn’t difficult to make for any seasoned cook. My family absolutely loved it! I’m making it again Christmas Day 2018 and am serving it with a delicious spinach blue cheese & caramelized pecan salad, assorted fall roasted vegetables seasoned with butter, brown sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg & cloves. I’m also making a small sweet potato casserole & homemade rolls. Desert will be a yummy cream cheese pumpkin pie! My mouth is watering already!
We made this for Christmas dinner. It was fabulous. Incredibly easy and very tasteful. We didn't change a thing. We'll use this recipe again this coming Christmas.

This turned out quite well, recommended. I followed the recipe without any changes, though I did allow the roast to rest at room temperature for an hour (as suggested by other reviewers) before putting it into the oven.
I have made this for 2 consecutive Christmases. I skip the celery and use more carrots which then turns into a yummy side dish.
Turned out great, loved the coating recipe as well.
I make prime rib every Christmas this is the best recipe in my 40 years of making prime rib. I just made it for the second time in a week. It is worth ten stars
I made this for Christmas dinner, and it was a huge success. I followed the recipe exactly, but watch the temp, it took less than 2 hours, and was almost medium.
It was delicious, every one loved it
A winner. Can't wait to do it again and will leave in the oven as suggested by one of your reviewers.....
The rub & the a jus were superb! Many positive comments. I cooked the meat too long however at the 500 degree temp. Next time I will know how much time to give it.
Perfect rib cant wait to make it again
This is a fantastic recipe for prime rib. Loved the au jus!! Made it without horseradish, because I didn’t have any, but was awesome without it. Was very easy to make.
This is my now go to prime rib. The crust is amazing. The roast perfect on the onside. I used a roast almost 6 pounds. Followed exactly. Love this recipe!
Great recipe! Will make it again!
I'm sticking with this one!

The roast turned out great! I tweaked it a little by rubbing it with Olive Oil and covering it with a rustic herb mixture. That made a great crust. The hit was the gravy! Very rich, tasty gravy. Then, I used the left over gravy as a base for beef barley stew. I threw in the left over roast and veggies.
Was easy and very tasty. Next time I will reduce the time in the oven by 15 or 20 mins.
It was excellent
I cooked this recipe on Christmas Day 2017 and my family loved it.

This is the first time for fixing prime rib at Christmas and it was so delicious (better than any restaurant) and was enjoyed by the family of 10.I baked this 10# prime rib about 2 hours that was about 15 minutes longer only because we prefer medium well. I did not make any additional changes and will definitely make it again. Thank you for sharing your recipes. Sue, Belpre OH
Outstanding. This will be an annual dinner. Really delicious.
No changes, and I will make it again! This was an easy recipe and the roast came out very tender. I did not have much juice to work with for au jus, however, for some reason.
Followed recipe pretty closely and it came out fine. Did not have beef paste, so substituted 1 cup beef stock with 1/2 cup red wine for paste/water. Will make this again.
really good
Followed instructions exactly and had great results. My husband said it's the best prime rib he's ever had.
I made two one plain and the other with the horseradish Dijon crusting. That one flew off the plate! My 18 year old grand son said “grandpa this one hit the mark!” Nuff said.
I think that this was absolutely the best meat dish that I have ever prepared. It was absolutely delicious and I would love to make it an annual Christmas tradition.
This was delicious and I will definitely make it again!
Turned out perfect. Made according to the recipe except for decreasing garlic powder to 1 tsp. After lowering the oven temperature, it took approx. 2 hours for a 7 lb. roast. Highly recommended.
Hardly anyone in the family likes horseradish or spice mustard. They loved the taste and a 10lb roast was all gone. Thanks
Nice flavor. I rubbed minced garlic on the outside and let it sit in the refrigerator for 2 hours before proceeding on to the butter rub.
This is the best recipe ever! Made this for Christmas and it was spectacular. Prepared just as directed, but didn't make an au jus. Had a 6.43 prime rib and meat was perfectly cooked to medium rare.

I bought a 5.5 lb. rib eye roast (on the bone) from King Soopers stores at $4.47 lb. I had the butcher cut the roast from the rib and had him tie it back to the bones (3). It came out of the oven perfectly at 135 degrees. When I cut into it, it was medium rare. Yummm.

Absolutely delicious !!! We did follow the recipe other than adding a few more veggies on the bottom and a bit of water in the pan during cooking. We willl definately use this recipe again !! Thank You

Outstanding! This recipe will replace our previous method of a dry-rub and garlic cloves. We used the ratio of 1 day/pound to dry-age the beef. We loved the horseradish/mustard mixture on the outside, along with the blend of spices. The horseradish (hot variety) was definitely not overpowering. We followed the recipe to the end of step 1, then my husband indirect grilled the roast over charcoal with a drip pan underneath the roast. We've done this grilling method many times, and it always comes out perfect. We base grilling time on 20 minutes/pound of roast. We remove from the grill when internal temperature reaches 120 degrees, then tent with foil and let stand 15 minutes. Since there was just the 2 of us this time, we had a 1-rib roast. They won't stay upright their own, so I used the tallest loop of our beer can chicken stand to hold the roast upright. It worked great! I think a rib rack would also work good, but ours wasn't accessible. Thanks for this delicious recipe.
Recipe is awesome. Only change I made was rather than use garlic powder I placed fresh garlic pieces inside the fat. The au jus was delicious.
Fantastic!! Wish I could give it ten stars. Add more carrots to the roasting pan. They awesome after cooking in the drippings.
Awesome!!!!
